segments.text: Now, did the Navy interest you, and the Navy specifically contact you about trying to discover what happens to sound in the ocean?
Yes, Ross and Bennett came out with the scripts.
Talked to Spurrier, but Fleming and me.
Okay, and how long did you work on that?
Oh, quite a while.
Okay.
Did that carry on to when you began to work in the Navy in 1941?
Yeah.
Okay.
We didn't start until about 1940.
Oh, all right.
Now, you said one time that the
that the 1950s and 60s will be recorded as one of the great ages of exploration, for an exact quote.
But it seems to me from your discussion here that the 30s must have been a great age of exploration.
What seems to you to be the difference in the two?
The scale.
The scale, okay.
What major changes in technique would you suggest that occurred between the 50s and 60s and the 30s?
The introduction of electronics.
We used to have a saying in the 1930s, early 1940s, we wanted less than one vacuum tube per instrument.
The great difference was really the development of instrumentation during World War II.
In the 1950s and the 1960s, we were exploiting that
Those great advances, not so much in actual instruments as in how to make instruments.
And you think that the development of instrumentation came out of the work in the military services?
Pretty largely, yeah.
Now, I'm familiar with the work that came out of the Air Force School of Meteorology that develops between 1942 and 1945.
It produced a goodly number of well-known oceanographers.
What about the U.S. Navy?
What would you suggest to be their major developments between 1941 and 1945?
In what?
In terms of instrumentation.
Well, the main thing was the development of underwater sounds of all kinds, both echo sounders and horizontal ranging devices.
great interest that developed in the Navy in the propagation of sound in the ocean.

But there were also developments in what we call magnetometers, that is, methods of measuring various magnetic phenomena on the bottom and in the water by the so-called towed magnetometer, which really came out of the work on magnetic mines.
Now, weren't you in the radio and sound lab in San Diego in 41 and 42?
What exactly was your work there?
Well, I was in a sailor's suit.
I forgot to tell you that in 1934, I went on a cruise on the USS Bushnell, which is the flagship of the submarine force.
It was just one submarine force, Atlantic and Pacific.
And the Bushnell went up to Alaska, about halfway out on the Aleutian Islands, and then south to Hawaii.

And I ran a line of oceanographic stations between the Aleutian Islands and the Hawaiian Islands, one of the first oceanographic sections across that part of the Pacific, really the first section across that part of the Pacific.
This was primarily physical oceanography, as we used to call it, and chemical oceanography.
That is, measurements of the silica, the oxygen, the nitrate, the phosphate, the temperature and salinity of the water.
And it was those data that I went to Norway with in 1936, 37.
And as a result of this experience on the Bushnell,
The captain of the ship was a man named Abel T. Bidwell.
I remember his name.
And I also remember the name of the admiral.
His name was Cyrus W. Cole.
This was a great experience in my life, this trip, this summer on this Navy ship.
There were various other people on board.
One was a man named Leo Bachmann.
I remember him quite well.
I don't remember the names of the others.
Anyhow, Bidwell persuaded me to try for a Naval Reserve Commissioner, which I did, and I got that in 1936.

So in 1941, when this Navy Radio and Sound Labs got started here in San Diego, and when the University of California Division of War Research was established there, I went on active duty and became a project officer for various kinds of things.
Whereas Fairdrip and Fleming and Walter Monk and the others worked as civilians in the University of California in the Division of War Research.
We had a skipper of the Navy Radio and Sound Laboratory.
It was a martinet named Red Rubel.
He was a real sundowner.
This means various things to me, but in his case it meant he was a complete son of a pig.
That's what it meant in the Army, sir.
He was an impossible man.
And I was on his staff.
And he would send us, he would send me out with a group of chief petty officers and one or two scientists on various kinds of field expeditions.
For example, in San Francisco Bay, we looked at the
oceanographic conditions at the mouth of the Golden Gate, and then we did the same thing up at Neah Bay at the mouth of the Straits of Juan Fuca.
Two of the scientists on those expeditions were Waldo Lyon, who has since become a great expert on the Arctic Oceanography.
He was a physicist, a young physicist from UCLA, and a man named Jeffrey Holder, H-O-L-T-E-R,
who was an idea man.
He was a graduate student of physics, too.
Idea men are a very peculiar breed, as you probably know.
They have lots of ideas, and most of them are not very good, but some of them are very good.
He was constantly interested in the original experiments of various kinds.
Anyhow, we worked together on these surveys.
Every time I came back to the survey, I found I had a different desk and a different job.
And I got involved with radar propagation.
I started a radar operator's school at the Navy Radio and Sound Laboratory, which later became the CIC school that still exists down here in San Diego.
a great big establishment now, but it started with six scared, stupid, enlisted men who were sent by their skippers because they didn't know what else to do with them.
To be our first class.
They were just awful.
But we decided we just couldn't teach guys like this how to operate radars.
We'd have to have standards.
So we insisted after that that
We would only take people who had passed a certain score on the Navy's intelligence test.
In fact, I've forgotten the name of it.
But it wasn't called an intelligence test, but that's really what it was.
And after that, they got better, and this thing really developed.
After a while, it developed into a great big establishment.
But this was, of course, a very dull job, teaching radar operators.
to teach the same thing over and over again.
And the one saving grace of it was that we would range on San Clemente Island.
It's about 70 miles west of San Diego.
And sometimes you could see it, and sometimes you couldn't.
And why was this?
Well, it turned out, of course, the reason was that the radar beam was refracted by the structure of the atmosphere.
Sometimes it was bent down.
Sometimes it wasn't bent.
And there were two good physicists who got involved with this.
One was named Frank Abbott.
And I can't think of the name of the other one.
I know him very well.
And of course, once they got into it, well, I had to fade away.
I just didn't know enough, electromagnetic theory.
That was one of the problems of being a geologist, was that you never really knew much about anything.
But the first paper on radar propagation written out here was, I was one of the authors of that.
And this, of course, has now become a science all by itself.
This was in the, so I really got out of the,
of the sound propagation study by getting involved with this radar school.
And my friend, Rosson Bennett, by this time had gone to Washington as the head of the design branch of the electronics division of the Bureau of Ships.
And I got in touch with him and said, I just got to get out of here.
This is impossible.
So he arranged for me to come to Washington.
be assigned to the hydrographic office.
This was in the winter of 1942.
I went out to the hydrographic office.
The hydrographer was an old guy, a nice old admiral named Brian.
Didn't really have any idea about World War II or what in the world an oceanographer could do.
So he put me to work looking at a bank.
that had been found somewhere off the coast of Panama.
This bank was very interesting because it didn't exist.
Some ships had picked it up on their bathometers, on their echo cylinders.
And other ships passing over the same spot couldn't find it.
Clearly, what it was was a deep scattering.
But the guys out here were just finding out about the deep scattering layer at that time.
Yeah, they were working out here in the Office of Naval Research.
Oh, that was the University of California Division of War Research.
Division of War Research, right.
Russell Raitt and Martin Johnson, particularly.
They did two great things.
One was to find the deep scattering layer.
The other was to, Martin Johnson, to solve the problem of crackle, the background noise that you got from mines.
not front lines, but background noise that got into the sonar gear, which affected also acoustic lines.
It turned out the way Martin did this was to ask, well, in fact, Martin was responsible for both these discoveries.
In the case of the deep scattering layer, he asked the following question, what happens to it at night?
And the
And it turned out that at night it didn't exist.
The scattering was just below the surface, not at depths of 100 or 200 meters.
He said it must be due to organisms, because that's the way marine organisms behave.
They go down in the daytime and up at night.
And that, of course, is what turned out was right.
In the case of the crackle, he said, where does it exist?
And it didn't exist everywhere.
It only existed over certain kinds of bottoms.
And he said that he guessed that these must be an organism called a snapping shrimp, which lives in rocky bottoms and sandy bottoms, not in muddy bottoms.
And he got some of these shrimp.
He got one shrimp and put it in a little jar and put a microphone in the jar and called it a hydrophone because it's underwater.
continuous popping noise like bacon fries.
And clearly that was what it was.
So these were two biological discoveries of very considerable interest.
But anyhow, that was what Brian wanted me to do with this bank, this non-existent bank.
I didn't think that was a very military thing to do.

So I went back to Ross and Bennett, and he said, well, we'll give you additional duty in the Bureau of Ships, in the underwater sound section of the Bureau of Ships, the underwater sound section of the design branch of the electronics division of the Bureau of Ships.
And I became code 940C, or 940D, I guess it was.
My boss was a
a man named Jacob Myers, a wonderful guy about my age.
He was a commander, and I started out as a lieutenant and eventually became a commander myself.
And we got along very well.
I became the Bureau of Ships oceanographer, and I worked with all kinds of people.
And I really became project officer for work that was being done at Woods Hole and at Scripps.

the oceanographic work in radio and sound at the University of California Division of War Research, and the related work that was being done in New London in the underwater, a place called USNASL, U.S. Navy Underwater Sound Lab.
Now, was Sir Edward Bullard involved in that?
No, he was in England.
I mean, the one in England.
He was involved in many things, but the two principal things he did during the war were to work on acoustic, on the
first on the magnetic minds, and then on acoustic minds, and finally on the so-called oyster mind.
The oyster mind was a diabolical device.
It still is diabolical.
It depends upon the negative pressure wave made by the passage of a ship.
And you can't sweep it.
The only thing that was sweepable set it off as a ship.
So you could sweep it by dragging the ship along.
And the other thing he was involved with was the operating research business.
He's a first-rate physicist, and had done a lot of geophysical work even before the war, measurements of gravity and measurements of magnitude.
I would say that he's probably the greatest living geophysicist.
But anyhow, I never met him during the war at all.
We did come in contact with George Deacon, my group.
I worked very closely with a man named Lyman Spitzer, who is now a professor of astronomy at Princeton, and after the war went into the thermonuclear fusion business.
He's a very, very able man.
He has an IQ about 40 points higher than mine.
No problem was too difficult for him.
He was fantastic.
And he had something called the Underwater Sonar Analysis Group, which was part of the NDRC.
And I was his opposite number in the Bureau of Ships.
So we worked very closely together for many years, all during the war and after the war.
Out here at Scripps, or at UCDWR, rather,
I worked with Carl Eckhardt, who was also a first-rate physicist.
He was a theoretical physicist.
Like so many theoretical physicists in the 1920s, who started in the 1920s, he came very close to
to winning a Nobel Prize, but didn't.
Because these guys were all in competition with each other in Germany.
Somebody else came up with the publication a few weeks before he did.
But up until 1941, he was a professor of theoretical physics at the University of Chicago.
His student was Leonard Lieberman.
He's still on the faculty of Scripps.
Carl Eckhardt himself died two years ago, three years ago.
And Eckhardt really revolutionized the underwater sound business by treating it statistically rather than by this ray theory of ours.
I don't think I understand that.
What's the difference between a ray theory and a statistic treatment?
In the ray theory, we essentially assumed that the sound waves followed a path, a single path.
And the ray is essentially at right angles to the wave.
You can trace the path of the wave by drawing a ray.
That gives you some useful insights.
But statistical theory was more powerful because, in fact, the ocean is so complicated.

The problems of reverberation, for example, the problems of background noise, the problems of scattering, and of absorption of sound are all related to the microstructure of the ocean as well as to the macrostructure.
The best way to study these things is to look at the statistics, that is, what's the frequency of different events.
You study reverberation, what's the pattern of reverberation, statistical pattern, and time.
One of the great advantages of this is that you can integrate over time.
He was a, he'd written a famous paper, what he called Irreversible Thermodynamics, which he dealt with phenomena of this general kind, phenomena of hydrodynamic, thermodynamic phenomena.
And this was written actually before the war.
And his interest really shifted then from nuclear physics and atomic physics to this field of hydrodynamics and thermodynamics.
And he made great contributions into the theory of it, but never very much to the end.
And to some extent to the practice, too.
He wrote a classical.
series of volumes after the war on the propagation of underwater sound, right after the war.
Still, probably the most important book ever written on the subject, series of books, written for the NDRC, National Defense Research Committee.
And there were a lot of people down there at the CDWR who were developing instrumentation
and had ideas of various kinds about the various kinds of energy in the ocean.
One of the amusing stories was that when we were first there, it was full of hot shots from the physics department at Berkeley, led by Ernest Lawrence.
They had McMillan and a whole group of people.
Lawrence had the idea that these damned ocean arguments were stupid, which they were.
And the thing to do instead of fooling around with sound, as we had been doing, was to just get a big light underwater and he'd see us up there.
And his idea was that
What we'd been doing is fooling around with things that were too small and too inexpensive.
If you just got a big enough light, you'd be able to see a long way.
So they started a whole optical group down at DC, at DWR, under his direction, or at least his inspiration, headed actually by a man named Ike Bowen of Caltech, who was the later director of the
a very nice, competent man.
And they built this huge searchlight with millions of candle power.
And they had a black sock 20 feet across and a couple hundred feet long to be a sort of imitation submarine.
And the problem was how far it went.
And then they tested out the searchlight.
Well, you could see this sock about 20 feet short.
Well, Lawrence decided maybe this wasn't such a good idea.
The problem, of course, was that the scattering of light in the water created so much background that you didn't get any contrast.
But they made a lot of studies of the propagation of light and the transmission of light in the ocean.
And they had several problems which we oceanographers thought we could help them with.
And we could.
One of the problems was the damn instruments leaked.
Of course, they'd never done any work on this.
It's really a very difficult condition of salt water and pressure, high pressure, highly corrosive water.
And so they'd lower the thing in the water and ruin everything.
They'd have to take it out and start all over again.
Finally, they got them so they wouldn't leak.
And they went out and made a series of measurements about
50 miles offshore here and measured the transmission at different depths.
And the guy that did it was a man named Malcolm Henderson.
He said, OK, we measured the transmission of light in the seawater.
And Sverdrup and I said, well, why don't you go over here and try it again?
We knew we were on the inside of a front.
Well, he finally did, and of course, he got completely different results.
There's no relationship at all between the two, between the set two series of measurements.
And so the next conclusion was you can't measure the transmission of light and see why it's too variable.
So we said, well, now you go over here, and you'll find it's like it was the first time.
You go there, and you'll find it like it was the second time, which of course was true, more or less.
But anyhow, they had kind of lost interest in us because this damn sock didn't work very well.
And then anyhow, all these hot shots disappeared all of a sudden.
And we had heard that they went to a place called Shangri-La.
And this was, of course, Los Alamos, as we found out after the war.
still quite a few physicists left and quite a few engineers left.
And they worked for years on a mine detecting.
One of the big things they did was work on a mine detecting sonar.
Well, they didn't start out that way.
They started out with what they called variable frequency sonar, essentially frequency modulated sonar.
And it turned out that this might be useful in detecting mines.
And we had a submarine force had a real problem.
They couldn't get it to the Japan Sea.
because the Japanese had planted floating mines in Tsushima Strait and the other strait between Hokkaido and Honshu.
And all during the war until the summer of 1945, none of our submarines ever went into the Japanese sea.
But finally, we and the Bureau of Ships, in this section I'm telling you about,
the underwater sound section, managed to get 12 submarines equipped with these sonars developed here at San Diego, at the UCDWR.
And they did go into the Japan Sea.
And this is the irony of it.
By that time, the Japan Sea was essentially empty.
They sank 25,000 tons of shipping and lost a submarine.
And what had happened was that the oyster mines had been planted in all the Japanese harbors.
And it essentially just stopped.
All traffic back and forth from then showed up.
These were planted by the 29th Bomb Com, the 29th Bomber Command, flying up from Marianas.
And they dropped these mines in the harbors.
I was at the harbors, and the Japanese just couldn't get through them.
